title: Sirius Minerals insists there are no plans to take business private
text:
Sirius Minerals has insisted there are no plans to take the business private following controversial comments made by its boss.

Chief executive Chris Fraser last week suggested the company, which plans to build a £4 billion potash mine under the North York Moors National Park, may be better off quitting the stock market.

In an interview with the Mail, Fraser (pictured) said: 'Where we are now, I think we might be better off being a private company, because sentiment, short-sellers and all those sort of features are massively distorting the value of the company.'

The comments alarmed the firm's 85,000-strong army of small investors, including many families in villages around the moors who have seen the value of their shares tumble since backing Sirius.

The company last month failed to secure a £400m bond that would have unlocked funding required to complete its £4 billion Woodsmith mine under the North York Moors National Park. Fraser added: 'As I see it today, there's potential merit in being private simply to get away from the capital markets.'

He told the Mail he blamed markets for Sirius's struggles to raise more cash, saying banks and other big institutions that would usually commit to funding were 'failing' companies.

The chief executive's comments came at a sensitive time for Sirius, which is in a review process and has publicly said it is weighing up two options – either trying to raise more funding through the debt markets or by bringing in a strategic investor.

The business has enough money to keep trading until next spring but it is also cutting costs – including hundreds of jobs – in the meantime.

Bringing in a partner would likely cement investors' losses as it would dilute current shareholders' stakes.

But after Fraser's intervention, Sirius said there were no plans to quit the stock market. A spokesman added: 'Our focus is on completing our strategic review and unlocking the value of our project for our shareholders, our community, and the UK as a whole.'

Fraser brought Sirius to the market in 2011 by reversing his group, York Potash, into an existing company.

The ambitious mining project, based a few miles away from the seaside town of Whitby, grabbed the imagination of 85,000 retail investors who piled in to support the company.

Its share price hit a high of 44p in 2016 but has since tumbled to 3.4p last night, falling another 4.3 per cent, or 0.15p yesterday, stinging retail investors for their loyalty.

Someone who bought £10,000 of shares in August 2016 would have around £766-worth now.

While Sirius's mining project has huge set-up costs, the company has always insisted that, once constructed, it would be cheap to run.

As well as building two mile-deep shafts to get to a deposit of polyhalite, it is also constructing a 23-mile-long tunnel to house a conveyor belt that would transport chipped pieces of rock from the mine to a port on Teesside.

There, it would be crushed and processed into fine granules that could easily be spread on crops by farmers.
